questions.correct_answer: C. High intensity signal: Increase in water content in myelin tracts
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High intensity signal: Increase in water content in myelin tracts High intensity signal : This T2 - weighted MRI feature represents an increase in water content in myelin tracts.

Highyeild:

High intensity signal : This T2 - weighted MRI feature represents an increase in water content in myelin tracts undergoing Wallerian degeneration secondary to cortical motor neuronal loss . Example- Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) (most common) Aids-related encephalopathy Infarction Other disease processes that produce corticospinal neuronal loss in a symmetric fashion. 437-1 Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan through the lateral ventricles of the brain reveals abnormal high signal intensity within the corticospinal tracts (arrows). This MRI feature represents an increase in water content in myelin tracts undergoing Wallerian degeneration secondary to cortical motor neuronal loss. This finding is commonly present in ALS but can also be seen in AIDS-related encephalopathy, infarction, or other disease processes that produce corticospinal neuronal loss in a symmetric fashion.

Beevor’s sign Procedure- Patient supine; asked to hook finger behind neck; raise head towards feet ; abdominal wall contracts → umbilicus moves up (Beevor’s sign). It occurs because the upper abdomen muscles, such as the rectus abdominis, are intact at the top of the abdomen but weak at the lower portion . questions.text: A 36-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to weakness of his upper and lower extremities. Neurological examination reveals weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, spasticity, and hyperreflexia of the involved muscles. His sensory, bowel, bladder, and cognitive functions are intact. Serum creatine kinase is normal. The cerebrospinal fluid examination is within normal limits. Electromyography shows chronic partial denervation. Which of the following has been approved for use with this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Riluzole The patient is suffering from Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis As he has a pure motor neuron lesion sparing sensory, bowel and bladder, and Both UMN (hyperreflexia,spasticity ) and LMN lesion features (atrophy, chronic partial denervation). Riluzole is a glutamate inhibitor that is currently approved for use in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Although it cannot arrest the underlying pathological process, it may prolong survival and the time to tracheostomy . It is a well tolerated drug Its side effects are dizziness, nausea, weight loss , elevated liver enzymes and skeletal weakness. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease . Corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulins and cyclophosphamide have no role in its management . These agents are used in the management of immunologically-mediated neurological diseases.

Highyeild:

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis- No treatment arrests the underlying pathologic process in ALS . Riluzole produces a modest lengthening of survival. glutamate inhibitor Edaravone antioxidant combined oral administration of phenylbutyrate and taurus ursodiol slow progression and prolong survival in ALS by improving function in mitochondria and the endoplasmic reticulum. antisense oligonucleotides (ASO) microRNAs diminish expression of mutant SOD1 protein prolong survival experimental trials small molecules mesenchymal stem cells immunosuppression. Rehabilitative aids Foot-drop splints Facilitate ambulation by obviating the need for excessive hip flexion by preventing tripping on a floppy foot. Finger Extension splints can potentiate grip. Respiratory support may be life-sustaining long-term ventilation by tracheostomy, positive-pressure ventilation by mouth or nose provides transient (weeks to months) relief from hypercarbia and hypoxia. Respiratory device (cough assist machine) produces an artificial cough. highly effective in clearing airways and preventing aspiration pneumonia. When bulbar disease prevents normal chewing and swallowing gastrostomy is uniformly helpful Restoring normal nutrition and hydration. Speech synthesizers augment speech in advanced bulbar palsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B Corticosteroids are used to treat acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis . Option: C, and D. IV immunoglobulin and Plasmapheresis - are the main treatment modalities of Guillain-Barre syndrome.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with a six month history of painless weakness in his right arm. Initially, this began with weakness of grip strength, but now involves a wrist drop. He denies any numbness. His examination demonstrates weakness in muscles innervated by the ulnar and radial nerves along with fasciculations. His triceps reflex is absent. Nerve conduction studies in the right arm demonstrate normal sensory responses and abnormal motor responses with conduction blocks present. These conduction blocks are outside of typical sites of compression. Electromyography shows fasciculations and decreased recruitment in ulnar and radial innervated muscles. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Anti-GM1 antibodies are frequently found in this condition

options.label: B
options.text: Riluzole is the recommended treatment for this condition

options.label: C
options.text: Diagnosis can be confirmed by lumbar puncture demonstrating cyto-albuminological dissociation

options.label: D
options.text: This condition is caused by a virus in the Picornaviridae family

questions.correct_answer: A. Anti-GM1 antibodies are frequently found in this condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti-GM1 antibodies are frequently found in this condition. This patient has Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN) with a Conduction Block . The patient has LMN lesion signs(fasciculations, absent deep tendon reflexes) with hallmark features of MMCB on Nerve conduction studies ( normal sensory responses and abnormal motor responses with conduction blocks present. These conduction blocks are outside of typical sites of compression.

Highyeild:

Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) with a conduction block(MMCB)- This is commonly misdiagnosed as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) because it is a pure motor disorder with fasciculations. Lower motor neuron function is regionally and chronically disrupted by focal blocks in conduction. The keys to discerning MMN from ALS(Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) include A lack of upper motor neuron findings in MMN key electrodiagnostic findings. Normal sensory responses with at least two motor nerves with conduction blocks outside of typical areas of entrapment. (Hallmark of MMN) Anti-GM1 antibodies (50% patients of MMN) hypothesized that the antibodies produce selective, focal, paranodal demyelination of motor neurons. MMCB is not typically associated with corticospinal signs. In contrast with ALS , MMCB may respond dramatically to therapy such as IV immunoglobulin or chemotherapy Thus, it is imperative that MMCB be excluded when considering a diagnosis of ALS.

Diagnosis can be confirmed by lumbar puncture demonstrating cyto-albuminological dissociation as seen in GBS Option: D. This condition is caused by a virus in the Picornaviridae family (Polio is in the Picornaviridae family), and causes a pure lower motor neuropathy , but there would be no conduction blocks on nerve conduction studies.

questions.text: 44-year-old Mr. Sethi presents to your outpatient clinic with a six month history of dysphagia and dysarthria. On examination he has mild upper and lower facial weakness, tongue atrophy with fasciculations, and bilateral proximal arm weakness. His reflexes are normal throughout, and sensory examination is unremarkable. He has noted mild gynecomastia, impotence, and testicular atrophy. Which of the following is true of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common genetic cause of this disease is a mutation in the C9ORF72 gene

options.label: B
options.text: This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder inherited in an X-linked recessive manner

options.label: C
options.text: This is an autoimmune condition caused by antibodies to the muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MUSK) protein

options.label: D
options.text: This disorder is treated with chelation therapy with penicillamine

questions.correct_answer: B. This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder inherited in an X-linked recessive manner
questions.explanation:
Solution:

This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. The patient has Kennedy disease as he is male , with progressive weakness of bulbar muscle features and has gynecomastia, impotence, testicular atrophy .

Highyeild:

Kennedy disease(Spinobulbar muscular atrophy)- This is an X-linked lower motor neuron disorder The underlying molecular defect is an expanded trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the first exon of the androgen receptor gene on the X chromosome . An inverse correlation appears to exist between the number of CAG repeats and the age of onset of the disease. P rogressive weakness and wasting of limb and bulbar muscles begin in males in mid-adult life and are conjoined with androgen insensitivity manifested by gynecomastia and reduced fertility . In addition to gynecomastia, which may be subtle, two findings distinguishing this disorder from ALS are the absence of signs of pyramidal tract disease (spasticity) and the presence of a subtle sensory neuropathy in some patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The most common genetic cause of this disease is a mutation in the C9ORF72 gene. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis has several genetic causes, including SOD1 and, more recently, C9ORF72. Option: C. This is an autoimmune condition caused by antibodies to the muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MUSK) protein - MUSK antibodies are associated with myasthenia gravis. Option: D. This disorder is treated with chelation therapy with penicillamine - Wilson disease is treated with chelation therapy such as penicillamine . It can cause dysarthria, but not typically fasciculations, testicular atrophy, or gynecomastia .

questions.explanation:

Statement c. Even in the late stages of the illness, sensory, bowel and bladder, and cognitive functions are preserved. Statement d. Mutations in C9orf72 account for 45–50% of Familial ALS and perhaps 5% of sporadic ALS cases. Adult Tay-Sachs Disease Several reports have described adult onset, predominantly lower motor neuropathies arising from deficiency of the enzyme β-hexosaminidase (hex A) . These tend to be distinguishable from ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) because they are very slowly progressive and in some cases may have been symptomatic for years; dysarthria and radiographically evident cerebellar atrophy may be prominent. In rare cases, spasticity may also be present, although it is generally absent.

questions.text: Which of the following spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) has the earliest onset and most rapidly fatal course?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Werdnig-Hoffmann disease Infantile SMA (SMA I, Werdnig-Hoffmann disease)- has the earliest onset and most rapidly fatal course . In some instances, it is apparent even before birth, as indicated by decreased fetal movements late in the third trimester. Though alert, afflicted infants are weak and floppy (hypotonic) and lack muscle stretch reflexes. Death generally ensues within the first year of life.

Highyeild:

Spinal Muscular Atrophy The SMAs are a family of selective lower motor neuron diseases of early onset. Despite some phenotypic variability largely in age of onset , these disorders are characterized by extensive loss of large motor neurons ; muscle biopsy reveals evidence of denervation atrophy . Clinical forms are- Infantile SMA (SMA I, Werdnig-Hoffmann disease)- has the earliest onset and most rapidly fatal course . -Chronic childhood SMA (SMA II) begins later in childhood and evolves with a more slowly progressive course. -Juvenile SMA (SMA III, Kugelberg-Welander disease) manifests during late childhood and runs a slow, indolent course. -Adult SMA(SMA IV)
